title: White or very blond hair is quite common amongst people in Scandinavia. Has this at some point in history been influenced by something like Nazi invasions from the Hitler Youth or what is the reason to blond hair being so common there? - Quora

response.answer_text: Blonde hair did not originate in Scandinavia. The oldest remains carrying the genes for blonde hair were found among the Ancient Northern Eurasian (ANE) Anfontova Gora Complex in Russia and dated to 14 000 years. The descendants of the ANE, the Eastern hunter gatherers who had blonde hair, migrated into Northern Europe during the Mesolithic and that is why there are so many blondes in Scandinavia. Afontova Gora - Wikipedia Afontova Gora is no. 2 on this map:  The Indo-Europeans who were 50% Eastern hunter gatherers and Iran in origin migrated into Europe about 4000 - 3000 years ago and interbred with the blonde, blue eyed hunter gatherers already living in Europe. The Indo-Europeans then took the genes for blonde hair throughout Europe, the Middle East, Central Asia and all the way to China and Mongolia. You need to stop believing Nazi propaganda. It wasn't true in the 1930s or 1940s, and it's not true today. There are a lot of blond Germans, but there are also a lot of dark haired Germans (like Hitler was). Scandinavians tend to be blond because most Scandinavians have genes for blond hair. They had blond hair for generations before World War II, and while Norway was occupied by the Nazis, it wouldn't have been enough to change the dominant hair color for the entire region. And given that Scandinavians are more likely to be blond than Germans, the Nazi occupation was likely to produce fewer blond Norwegians, not more.

Blond hair and pale skin is a genetic variation which is naturally selected for in areas of weak and limited sunlight. It takes many generations for such selection to take place on more than an individual basis. In terms of humans that involves centuries if not millenia. While NAZI ideology idealised blond hair, blue eyes and a pale skin that was just propaganda. Most Germans don’t fit that stereotype and in any case were only in Norway and Denmark (not Sweden) for a few years - not long enough to alter the genetic makeup of an entire country.

It is the most common hair color there! No need for the stupid Nazi invasions! Most Scandinavians are born blond - haired, and this hair color progressively darkens as they get older and there are others who retain it. I call it the standard Scandinavian hair color.
The German population was influenced by breeding with the Norse people who came to what is now Germany 5 thousand years ago.
